summary: This document is an email chain between Assistant U.S. Attorneys discussing a court order from Judge Engelmayer. The judge requested a declaration from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) to explain the disparities in discovery and counsel access between Ghislaine Maxwell (detained at MDC) and Justin Rivera (detained at MCC), which the defense argued were discriminatory. The emails detail the logistical and security justifications for the differing accommodations.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused co-conspirator of Jeffrey Epstein, detained at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) in protective custody. The email discusses the extensive accommodations she receives for reviewing discovery and meeting with counsel.

persons.name: Justin Rivera
persons.context: A defendant in a separate sex trafficking conspiracy case, detained at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in general population. His counsel raised concerns about unequal access to discovery and counsel compared to Maxwell.

persons.name: Judge Engelmayer
persons.context: The judge presiding over United States v. Rivera et al. He expressed frustration with the MCC's treatment of Rivera and ordered the government to submit a BOP declaration explaining the disparity in accommodations with Maxwell.

persons.name: Bhaskaran
persons.context: The sender of the initial email in the chain, informing colleagues about the judicial order and the need for a BOP declaration regarding disparities in inmate access.

connections.description: Both are federal detainees whose access to discovery and counsel accommodations are being compared by the court. They are not directly connected but are subjects of a judicial inquiry into equitable treatment.
Judge Engelmayer is presiding over Rivera's case and has intervened to address perceived inadequate accommodations for Rivera's trial preparation.
Bhaskaran, as an AUSA, is coordinating the government's response to Judge Engelmayer's order for a BOP declaration.

events.title: Defense Raises Disparity Issue
events.description: Defense counsel for Justin Rivera files a letter and argues in a court conference that the accommodations for Ghislaine Maxwell are "strikingly different and far superior," suggesting discrimination based on race, gender, and class.

events.title: Government Finalizes Response
events.description: Prosecutors finalize their explanation for the disparities, citing differences in discovery volume, housing situations (protective custody vs. general population), and facility logistics at MDC vs. MCC.

events.title: BOP Declaration Deadline
events.description: Court-ordered deadline for the government to submit a declaration from the Bureau of Prisons explaining the rationale for differing accommodations between Maxwell and Rivera.

events.title: Scheduled Trial for Rivera
events.description: The expected start date for Justin Rivera's trial on sex trafficking conspiracy charges.

locations: One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: Judge Engelmayer ordered the government to explain why Ghislaine Maxwell received significantly more access to discovery and counsel (13 hours/day laptop, 15 hours/week video) than Justin Rivera (3 hours/day laptop, 6 hours/week video).
The government's explanation centered on Maxwell's unique protective custody housing at MDC versus Rivera's general population housing at MCC, and the greater volume of discovery in Maxwell's case.
Defense counsel for Rivera alleged the disparity was due to discrimination based on Rivera's race, gender, and class, which the judge said created "terrible" optics.
By December 30, 2020, the MCC had begun leaving a laptop with Rivera all day, ostensibly matching Maxwell's level of electronic discovery access.
The email chain reveals internal DOJ coordination to craft a response to judicial scrutiny over equitable treatment of high-profile versus other detainees.
